author: Russia Today
title: Russia‚Äôs new hypersonic missile sends a ‚Äòstrong message‚Äô ‚Äì ex-US Army officer ‚Äî RT World News
text:
Moscow‚Äôs combat test of an intermediate-range hypersonic ballistic missile that can reach the entire European continent sends a ‚Äúvery strong message‚Äù to the US and the incoming administration of President-elect Donald Trump, believes former US Army officer Stanislav Krapivnik.
In an interview with RT on Thursday night, Krapivnik discussed what President Putin called a ‚Äúcombat test,‚Äù in which Russia‚Äôs new hypersonic missile, dubbed ‚ÄòOreshnik‚Äô (‚ÄòHazel‚Äô), successfully struck a military industrial facility in Dnipro (formerly Dnepropetrovsk) in Ukraine.
‚ÄúFirst of all, it sends a very strong message to the United States, because let's not forget it was Donald Trump who exited the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which forbade a whole category of missiles ‚Äì the very missiles that could have destroyed Europe. Interestingly enough, the European vassals said nothing against it,‚Äù he noted.
READ MORE: Russia has fired its new ‚ÄòOreshnik‚Äô hypersonic ballistic missile ‚Äì Putin According to Krapivnik, the United States had already been developing its own intermediate-range ballistic missiles at the time and decided to withdraw from the treaty under the false pretense that Russia was developing its own.
‚ÄúRussia turned around and developed a missile relatively quickly, and not just any missile but a hypersonic missile that travels at Mach 10. To understand what Mach 10 means, it‚Äôs three kilometers per second; your eye can't catch how fast it goes by,‚Äù Krapivnik explained.
The exact technical capabilities of the new nuclear-capable missile are classified, but according to Krapivnik‚Äôs estimates, it has a range of at least 3,000 kilometers and can carry about a dozen multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles.
‚ÄúSo the top opens up, and glide vehicles come out traveling at around Mach 10. Not all of them will carry nuclear warheads, as they are often used as decoys. This forces any defensive system to pick and choose its targets,‚Äù he said.
A problem here is that it doesn't matter what the system picks and chooses. There are absolutely no anti-missile systems in the world ‚Äì except perhaps for the Russian S-550 ‚Äì that can stop a hypersonic missile.
Moscow warned Washington about the impending strike 30 minutes in advance through a contact line designed to reduce the risks of nuclear confrontation, according to the Kremlin. However, Krapivnik stated that although the US obviously passed the notice to the authorities in Kiev, they still had no idea what to expect or what actually hit them.
‚ÄúThis is the first demonstration of the missile's capability,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got to remember one thing: two years ago, the US and its Western allies didn‚Äôt even believe that Russia had any hypersonic missiles because the prevailing attitude was, ‚ÄòWe're rich, Russia's poor, and there's no way they can develop anything.‚Äô Which shows absolute ignorance of the Russian economy and military capability.‚Äù

author: @zazoomblog
title: Acqualagna senza medico di base | intervenite
text:
Acqualagna senza medico di base | intervenite
Acqualagna si trova di fronte a una criticit√É sempre pi√É¬π grave: l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢assenza di un medico di base. Laura Biagiotti e Oriana Spini, consigliere di Minoranza, lanciano l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢allarme su un problema che rischia di compromettere la salute della comunit√É . La mancanza di interventi concreti e la mancata sostituzione di medici pensionati pongono il Comune in una situazione di emergenza. La questione richiede attenzione immediata e azioni concrete per garantire il diritto alla salute di tutti i cittadini.
Laura Biagiotti e Oriana Spini, consigliere di Minoranza di Acqualagna, mettono in guardia sulle carenze della sanit√É nel loro comune: "Quella che fino pochi anni fa era una situazione impensabile - rimanere senza medico di famiglia √¢‚Ç¨‚Äú √É¬® oggi una realt√É preoccupante, su cui cala un assordante silenzio. Anche ad Acqualagna, la questione del Medico di Medicina Generale ha raggiunto un√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢urgenza assoluta: l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ennesimo pensionamento non sostituito ha gettato i cittadini nella disperazione trovandosi privi del proprio medico di riferimento". Laura Biagiotti e Oriana Spini rimarcano con forza l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢importanza di questa situazione per la comunit√É : "La carenza di un medico di base genera notevoli disagi, rendendo difficoltoso l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢ottenimento di ricette, la prenotazione di prestazioni specialistiche tramite impegnativa e l√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢effettuazione di visite di controllo, mettendo a rischio la salute e il benessere dei paesani.
[üîó Leggi su Ilrestodelcarlino.it]
In questa notizia si parla di: medico - acqualagna - base - intervenite
Acqualagna senza medico di base: intervenite.
Medico di base lascia Matelica: "Regione e Ast devono intervenire" - Il Resto del Carlino - Medico di base lascia Matelica: "Regione e Ast devono intervenire" Il sindaco Cingolani ha scritto una lettera in cui chiede "La tempestiva integrazione per preservare il servizio". Da ilrestodelcarlino.it
Medici di base, la fuga continua: dottoressa veronese lascia per il troppo stress - Le nuove leve latitano: ?¬´Noi tutto il tempo a far ricette¬ª ... corrieredelveneto.corriere.it scrive

author: @odtnews
title: Warnings as wet weather hits much of NZ | Otago Daily Times Online News
text: You are not permitted to download, save or email this image. Visit [image gallery](/image_purchases) to purchase the image. Almost a full day of rain is likely for parts of New Zealand today and tonight, with some areas of the North Island already drenched. Hikers, campers and New Year‚Äôs Eve revellers are being warned to take care as thunderstorms, slips and flooding - including flooded rivers - are possible in the worst-hit areas. A warm, moist northwesterly flow is bring rain or showers to all parts of the country, with thunderstorms possible in northern and western parts of both islands and the deep south. Rain has also been bucketing down in Auckland since lunchtime. [Weather watches and warnings](https://www.metservice.com/warnings/home) have been in place since last night through till tomorrow, running from Waikato and Bay of Plenty down to Fiordland. Between 100-160mm of rain is possible in some warning areas. Forecaster Weatherwatch.co.nz said today would be marked by drizzle, dry spells and sudden downpours bringing a risk of localised flooding. The west of the South Island is bearing the brunt of the bad weather, along with Taranaki, which has been hit by torrential rain since this morning. A heavy rain warning is in place in the area through till 1am with a peak of 15-25 mm/h expected until mid-afternoon today. Westland is under a 21-hour heavy rain warning until 6am Saturday, with 100-140 mm of rain expected over that time and peak rates of 20-30mm/h. Nelson has a heavy rain warning until 7pm tonight with up to 90mm of rain in total. Heavy rain watches lasting 22 hours are in place for Buller, Waikato, Waitomo, Taumarunui, Taup≈ç, Tongariro National Park and the Kaimanawa Mountains, while Fiordland‚Äôs watch lasts for 20 hours. Rainfall amounts could reach warning criteria in all those areas, with thunderstorms also possible in many areas. Heavy rain means streams and rivers can rise rapidly and driving conditions may be hazardous, with possible surface flooding and slips. Thunderstorms are also possible in many areas, bringing intense localised downpours, according to MetService. The national forecaster‚Äôs meteorologist John Law said those thinking of going camping should keep an eye on the forecasts to avoid being stranded by sudden floods or slips. With heavy rain also expected across the Tararua Ranges and the Tongariro Crossing, keen hikers should also take care, Law said. New Year‚Äôs Day to bring drier weather The fast-moving weather system should improve by mid-Saturday but another front will bring more rain on Sunday, MetService says. But there‚Äôs good news as 2024 dawns - both MetService and private forecaster Weatherwatch expect the weather to clear for New Year‚Äôs Day. Weatherwatch head forecaster Philip Duncan said a big block of high pressure coming in from the Tasman Sea and Southern Ocean will bring clearing, cooler weather on January 1, with the recent high humidity taking a break.
